According to a United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America estimate, the pandemic-induced recession could leave 14–22 million more people in extreme poverty in Latin America than would have been in that situation without the pandemic.[514] According to the World Bank, up to 100 million more people globally could fall into extreme poverty due to the shutdowns.[515][516] The International Labour Organization (ILO) informed that the income generated in first nine months of 2020 from work across the world dropped by 10.7 per cent, or $3.5 trillion, amidst the coronavirus outbreak.[517]

Supply shortages

Main article: Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic
Coronavirus fears have led to panic buying of essentials across the world, including toilet paper, dried and instant noodles, bread, rice, vegetables, disinfectant, and rubbing alcohol.

The outbreak has been blamed for several instances of supply shortages, stemming from globally increased usage of equipment to fight outbreaks, panic buying (which in several places led to shelves being cleared of grocery essentials such as food, toilet paper, and bottled water), and disruption to the factory and logistic operations.[518] The spread of panic buying has been found to stem from perceived threat, perceived scarcity, fear of the unknown, coping behaviour and social psychological factors (e.g. social influence and trust).[519] The technology industry, in particular, has warned of delays to shipments of electronic goods.[520] According to the WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom, demand for personal protection equipment has risen a hundredfold, leading to prices up to twenty times the normal price and also delays in the supply of medical items of four to six months.[521][522] It has also caused a shortage of personal protective equipment worldwide, with the WHO warning that this will endanger health workers.[523]

The impact of the coronavirus outbreak was worldwide. The virus created a shortage of precursors (raw material) used in the manufacturing of fentanyl and methamphetamine. The Yuancheng Group, headquartered in Wuhan, is one of the leading suppliers.[524] Price increases and shortages in these illegal drugs have been noticed on the street of the UK.[525] U.S. law enforcement also told the New York Post Mexican drug cartels were having difficulty in obtaining precursors.[526]

The pandemic has disrupted global food supplies and threatens to trigger a new food crisis.[527][528] David Beasley, head of the World Food Programme (WFP), said "we could be facing multiple famines of biblical proportions within a short few months."[529] Senior officials at the United Nations estimated in April 2020 that an additional 130 million people could starve, for a total of 265 million by the end of 2020.[529][530][531]

Oil and other energy markets

In early February 2020, Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) "scrambled" after a steep decline in oil prices due to lower demand from China.[532] On Monday, 20 April, the price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) went negative and fell to a record low (minus $37.63 a barrel) due to traders' offloading holdings so as not to take delivery and incur storage costs.[533] June prices were down but in the positive range, with a barrel of West Texas trading above $20.[533]

Culture

Main article: List of events affected by the COVID-19 pandemic
Closed entrance to the Shah Abdol-Azim Shrine in Ray, Iran

The performing arts and cultural heritage sectors have been profoundly affected by the pandemic, impacting organisations' operations as well as individuals—both employed and independent—globally. Arts and culture sector organisations attempted to uphold their (often publicly funded) mission to provide access to cultural heritage to the community, maintain the safety of their employees and the public, and support artists where possible. By March 2020, across the world and to varying degrees, museums, libraries, performance venues, and other cultural institutions had been indefinitely closed with their exhibitions, events and performances cancelled or postponed.[534] In response there were intensive efforts to provide alternative services through digital platforms.[535][536][537]

An American Catholic military chaplain prepares for a live-streamed Mass in an empty chapel at Offutt Air Force Base in March 2020.

Holy Week observances in Rome, which occur during the last week of the Christian penitential season of Lent, were cancelled.[536] Many dioceses have recommended older Christians stay home rather than attend Mass on Sundays; services have been made available via radio, online live streaming and television, though some congregations have made provisions for drive-in worship.[538][539][536] With the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rome closing its churches and chapels and St. Peter's Square emptied of Christian pilgrims,[536] other religious bodies also cancelled in-person services and limited public gatherings in churches, mosques, synagogues, temples and gurdwaras.[536] Iran's Health Ministry announced the cancellation of Friday prayers in areas affected by the outbreak and shrines were later closed,[302][309] while Saudi Arabia banned the entry of foreign pilgrims as well as its residents to holy sites in Mecca and Medina.[540][541] The 2020 Hajj was limited to around 1,000 selected pilgrims, in contrast to the usual number of over 2 million.[542]

The pandemic has caused the most significant disruption to the worldwide sporting calendar since the Second World War. Most major sporting events have been cancelled or postponed, including the 2019–20 UEFA Champions League,[543] 2019–20 Premier League,[544] UEFA Euro 2020, 2019–20 NBA season,[545] and 2019–20 NHL season.[546] The outbreak disrupted plans for the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, which were originally scheduled to start at 24 July 2020, and were postponed by the International Olympic Committee to 23 July 2021.[547][548][549]

The entertainment industry has also been affected, with many music groups suspending or cancelling concert tours.[550][551] The Eurovision Song Contest, which was due to be held in Rotterdam, the Netherlands in May, was cancelled; however, the Netherlands was retained as host for 2021.[552][553] Many large theatres such as those on Broadway also suspended all performances.[554] Some artists have explored ways to continue to produce and share work over the internet as an alternative to traditional live performance, such as live streaming concerts[555] or creating web-based "festivals" for artists to perform, distribute, and publicise their work.[556] Online, numerous COVID-19-themed Internet memes have spread as many turn to humour and distraction amid the uncertainty.[557]

Politics

Main article: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on politics
See also: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on international relations

The pandemic has affected the political systems of multiple countries, causing suspensions of legislative activities,[558] isolations or deaths of multiple politicians,[559] and rescheduling of elections due to fears of spreading the virus.[560] Starting in late May, large-scale protests against police brutality in at least 200 U.S. cities and later worldwide in response to the killing of George Floyd raised concerns of a resurgence of the virus.[561]

Although they have broad support among epidemiologists, social distancing measures have been politically controversial in many countries. Intellectual opposition to social distancing has come primarily from writers of other fields, although there are a few heterodox epidemiologists.[562]

On 23 March 2020, United Nations Secretary-General António Manuel de Oliveira Guterres issued an appeal for a global ceasefire in response to the pandemic;[563][564] 172 UN Member States and Observers signed a non-binding statement in support of the appeal in June,[565] and the UN Security Council passed a resolution supporting it in July.[566][567]

China

Further information: China–United States relations § COVID-19

The Chinese government has been criticised by the United States government,[568] UK Minister for the Cabinet Office Michael Gove,[569] and others[570] for its handling of the pandemic. A number of provincial-level administrators of the Communist Party of China were dismissed over their handling of the quarantine measures in China, a sign of discontent with their response to the outbreak. Some commentators believed this move was intended to protect Chinese Communist Party general secretary Xi Jinping from the controversy.[571] The U.S. intelligence community says China intentionally under-reported its number of coronavirus cases.[572] The Chinese government maintains it has acted swiftly and transparently.[573][574]

Italy

In early March, the Italian government criticised the European Union's lack of solidarity with coronavirus-affected Italy[575][576]—Maurizio Massari, Italy's ambassador to the EU, said "only China responded bilaterally", not the EU.[577] On 22 March, after a phone call with Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, Russian president Vladimir Putin had the Russian army send military medics, disinfection vehicles, and other medical equipment to Italy.[578] President of Lombardy Attilio Fontana and Italian Foreign Minister Luigi Di Maio expressed their gratitude for the aid.[579] Russia also sent a cargo plane with medical aid to the United States.[580] Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said "when offering assistance to U.S. colleagues, [Putin] assumes that when U.S. manufacturers of medical equipment and materials gain momentum, they will also be able to reciprocate if necessary."[581] In early April, Norway and EU states like Romania and Austria started to offer help by sending medical personnel and disinfectant,[582] and Ursula von der Leyen offered an official apology to the country.[583]

United States

Several hundred anti-lockdown protesters rallied at the Ohio Statehouse 20 April.[584]

The outbreak prompted calls for the United States to adopt social policies common in other wealthy countries, including universal health care, universal child care, paid sick leave, and higher levels of funding for public health.[585][586][587] Political analysts believe it may have contributed to Donald Trump's loss in the 2020 presidential election.[588][589] Beginning in mid-April 2020, there were protests in several U.S. states against government-imposed business closures and restricted personal movement and association.[590] Simultaneously, protests ensued by essential workers in the form of a general strike.[591] In early October 2020, Donald Trump and many other government officials were diagnosed with COVID-19, further disrupting the country's politics.[592]

Other countries

The planned NATO "Defender 2020" military exercise in Germany, Poland, and the Baltic states, the largest NATO war exercise since the end of the Cold War, will be held on a reduced scale.[593][594] The Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament's general secretary Kate Hudson criticised the exercise, saying "it jeopardises the lives not only of the troops from the U.S. and the many European countries participating but the inhabitants of the countries in which they are operating."[595]

The Iranian government has been heavily affected by the virus, with about two dozen parliament members and fifteen current or former political figures infected.[312][596] Iran's President Hassan Rouhani wrote a public letter to world leaders asking for help on 14 March 2020, saying they were struggling to fight the outbreak due to a lack of access to international markets from the United States sanctions against Iran.[597] Saudi Arabia, which launched a military intervention in Yemen in March 2015, declared a ceasefire.[598]

Diplomatic relations between Japan and South Korea worsened due to the pandemic.[599] South Korea criticised Japan's "ambiguous and passive quarantine efforts" after Japan announced anyone coming from South Korea would be placed in quarantine for two weeks at government-designated sites.[600] South Korean society was initially polarised on President Moon Jae-in's response to the crisis; many Koreans signed petitions either calling for Moon's impeachment or praising his response.[335]

Some countries have passed emergency legislation in response to the pandemic. Some commentators have expressed concern that it could allow governments to strengthen their grip on power.[601][602] In the Philippines, lawmakers granted president Rodrigo Duterte temporary emergency powers during the pandemic.[603] In Hungary, the parliament voted to allow the prime minister, Viktor Orbán, to rule by decree indefinitely, suspend parliament as well as elections, and punish those deemed to have spread false information about the virus and the government's handling of the crisis.[604] In some countries, including Egypt,[605] Turkey,[606] and Thailand,[603] opposition activists and government critics have been arrested for allegedly spreading fake news about the COVID-19 pandemic.[607]

Agriculture and food systems

Further information: COVID-19 pandemic-related famines

The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted agricultural and food systems worldwide.[608] COVID-19 hit at a time when hunger or undernourishment was once again on the rise in the world, with an estimated 690 million people already going hungry in 2019.[609] Based on the latest UN estimates, the economic recession triggered by the pandemic may lead to another 83 million people, and possibly as many as 132 million, going hungry in 2020.[609][610][611][612] This is mainly due to a lack of access to food – linked to falling incomes, lost remittances and, in some cases, a rise in food prices. In countries that already suffer from high levels of acute food insecurity, it is no longer an issue of access to food alone, but increasingly also one of food production.[608][609]

The pandemic, alongside lockdowns and travel restrictions, has prevented movement of aid and greatly impacted food production. As a result, several famines are forecast, which the United Nations called a crisis "of biblical proportions,"[613] or "hunger pandemic."[614] It is estimated that without intervention 30 million people may die of hunger, with Oxfam reporting that "12,000 people per day could die from COVID-19 linked hunger" by the end of 2020.[615][613][616] This pandemic, in conjunction with the 2019–20 locust infestations and several ongoing armed conflicts, is predicted to form the worst series of famines since the Great Chinese Famine, affecting between 10 and 20 percent of the global population in some way.[617] 55 countries are reported to be at risk, with three dozen succumbing to crisis-level famines or above in the worst-case scenario.[618] 265 million people are forecast to be in famine conditions, an increase of 125 million due to the coronavirus pandemic.[615]

Education

Main article: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on education
The pandemic has severely impacted educational systems globally. Most governments have temporarily closed educational institutions, with many switching to online education. As of 30 September 2020, approximately 1.077 billion learners are currently affected due to school closures in response to the pandemic. According to UNICEF monitoring, 53 countries are currently implementing nationwide closures and 27 are implementing local closures, impacting about 61.6 percent of the world's student population. 72 countries' schools are currently open.[619]

School closures impact not only students, teachers, and families but have far-reaching economic and societal consequences. School closures in response to the pandemic have shed light on various social and economic issues, including student debt, digital learning, food insecurity, and homelessness, as well as access to childcare, health care, housing, internet, and disability services. The impact has been more severe for disadvantaged children and their families, causing interrupted learning, compromised nutrition, childcare problems, and consequent economic cost to families who cannot work.[citation needed]

Other health issues

Main article: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on other health issues

The pandemic has had many impacts on global health beyond those caused by the COVID-19 disease itself. It has led to a reduction in hospital visits for other reasons. There have been 38 per cent fewer hospital visits for heart attack symptoms in the United States and 40 per cent fewer in Spain.[620] The head of cardiology at the University of Arizona said, "My worry is some of these people are dying at home because they're too scared to go to the hospital."[621] There is also concern that people with strokes and appendicitis are not seeking timely treatment.[621] Shortages of medical supplies have impacted people with various conditions.[622]

In several countries there has been a marked reduction of spread of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV/AIDS, attributable to COVID-19 quarantines, social distancing measures, and recommendations to not engage in casual sex.[623][624] Similarly, in some places, rates of transmission of influenza and other respiratory viruses significantly decreased during the pandemic.[625][626][627]

The pandemic has also negatively impacted mental health globally, including increased loneliness resulting from social distancing[628] and depression and domestic violence from lockdowns.[629] As of June 2020, 40% of U.S. adults were experiencing adverse mental health symptoms, with 11% having seriously considered trying to kill themselves in the past month.[630]

Environment and climate

Main article: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the environment
Impact of coronavirus outbreak on environmental issues

Images from the NASA Earth Observatory show a stark drop in pollution in Wuhan, when comparing NO2 levels in early 2019 (top) and early 2020 (bottom).[631]

The worldwide disruption caused by the pandemic has resulted in numerous effects on the environment and the climate. The global reduction in modern human activity such as the considerable decline in planned travel[632] was coined anthropause[633] and has caused a large drop in air pollution and water pollution in many regions.[634] In China, lockdowns and other measures resulted in a 25 percent reduction in carbon emissions[635] and 50 percent reduction in nitrogen oxides emissions,[636] which one Earth systems scientist estimated may have saved at least 77,000 lives over two months.[637][638] Other positive effects on the environment include governance-system-controlled investments towards a sustainable energy transition and other goals related to environmental protection such as the European Union's seven-year €1 trillion budget proposal and €750 billion recovery plan "Next Generation EU" which seeks to reserve 25% of EU spending for climate-friendly expenditure.[639][640][641]

However, the outbreak has also provided cover for illegal activities such as deforestation of the Amazon rainforest[642][643] and poaching in Africa,[644][645] hindered environmental diplomacy efforts,[646] and created economic fallout that some predict will slow investment in green energy technologies.[647]

Xenophobia and racism

Main article: List of incidents of xenophobia and racism related to the COVID-19 pandemic

Since the start of the outbreak, heightened prejudice, xenophobia, and racism have been documented around the world toward people of Chinese and East Asian descent.[648][649][650] Reports from February (when most cases were confined to China) documented racist sentiments expressed in groups worldwide about Chinese people 'deserving' the virus.[651][652][653] Chinese people and other Asian in the United Kingdom and United States have reported increasing levels of racist abuse and assaults.[654][655][656] U.S. President Donald Trump has been criticised for referring to the coronavirus as the "Chinese Virus" and "Kung Flu", which has been widely condemned as racist and xenophobic.[657][658][659] On 14 March, an Asian family, including a two-year-old girl, was attacked at knifepoint in Texas in what the FBI has called a COVID-19 related hate crime.[660]

Following the progression of the outbreak to new hotspot countries, people from Italy (the first country in Europe to experience a serious outbreak of COVID-19) were also subjected to suspicion and xenophobia,[661][662] as were people from hotspots in other countries. Discrimination against Muslims in India escalated after public health authorities identified an Islamic missionary (Tablighi Jamaat) group's gathering in New Delhi in early March 2020 as a source of spread.[663] Paris has seen riots break out over police treatment of ethnic minorities during the coronavirus lockdown.[664] Racism and xenophobia towards southern and south east Asians increased in the Arab states of the Persian Gulf.[665][666][667] South Korea's LGBTQ community was blamed by some for the spread of COVID-19 in Seoul.[668][669] In China, some people of African descent were evicted from their homes and told to leave China within 24 hours, due to disinformation that they and other foreigners were spreading the virus.[670] This racism and xenophobia was criticised by foreign governments and diplomatic corps and the Chinese ambassador to Zimbabwe.[671]

Information dissemination

Further information: Media coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic, Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on social media, and Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on journalism

Ongoing COVID-19 research is indexed and searchable in the NIH COVID-19 Portfolio.[672] Some newspaper agencies removed their online paywalls for some or all of their coronavirus-related articles and posts,[673] while scientific publishers made scientific papers related to the outbreak available with open access.[674][675] Some scientists chose to share their results quickly on preprint servers such as bioRxiv.[676]

Misinformation

Main article: Misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic

The pandemic has resulted in misinformation and conspiracy theories about the scale of the pandemic and the origin, prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of the disease. False information, including intentional disinformation, has been spread through social media, text messaging, and mass media. It has also been reportedly spread by covert operations backed by states to generate panic and sow distrust in other countries. Journalists have been arrested for allegedly spreading fake news about the pandemic. It has also been propagated by celebrities, politicians, and other prominent public figures. A Cornell University study found that US President Donald Trump was "likely the largest driver" of the COVID-19 misinformation infodemic in the media.

Commercial scams have claimed to offer at-home tests, supposed preventives, and "miracle" cures. Several religious groups have claimed their faith will protect them from the virus. Some people have claimed the virus is a bioweapon accidentally or purposefully leaked from a laboratory, a population control scheme, the result of a spy operation, or the side effect of 5G upgrades to cellular networks.

The WHO has declared an "infodemic" of incorrect information about the virus, which poses risks to global health.

Notes

  1. ^ In summary, this article is about the coronavirus pandemic, which is caused by the disease COVID‑19, which in turn is caused by the virus SARS‑CoV‑2.
  2. ^ Known as "close contact" which is variously defined, including within ~1.8 metres (six feet) by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and being face to face for a cumulative total of 15 minutes,[6] or either 15 minutes of face to face proximity or sharing an enclosed space for a prolonged period such as two hours by the Australian Health Department.[7][8]
  3. ^ Some refer to this as 'infection fatality rate'; however the term 'ratio' is more accurate as this is not per unit time.[74]
  4. ^ This CDC best estimate (current as of 10 September) was derived from a paper in PLOS Medicine that estimated a range of IFR across several areas in Europe, from 0.5% (95% CrI 0.4%–0.6%) in Switzerland to 1.4% (95% CrI 1.1%–1.6%) in Lombardy, Italy (based on data through mid-to-late April).[64] Regarding the differences across the regions, the European researchers noted "the importance of local factors ... including demographic characteristics" and "the lower degree of preparedness and health service capacity in northern Italy, which in Europe was affected first by the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic."[64]
  5. ^ One set of national statistics for England (ONS) shows a decrease in IFR from 2.63% to 0.49%; another (MRC) from 0.69% to 0.30%, both over eight weeks ending 4 August.
  6. ^ Some refer to 'fatality rate'; however 'fatality ratio' is more accurate as this is not per unit time.[74]
  7. ^ Switzerland does not have an EUA procedure, but some vaccines have general or conditional use approval applications.
  8. ^ The United Kingdom,[149] Bahrain,[150] United Arab Emirates,[151] Canada,[152] Saudi Arabia,[153] the United States,[154] Mexico,[155] Kuwait,[156] Singapore,[157] Jordan,[158] Oman,[159] Ecuador,[160] Costa Rica,[161] Panama,[162] Chile,[163] and Switzerland.[164]
  9. ^ A lack of mass testing obscured the extent of the outbreak.[443]
